coredata.dc:title: Qualitative reasoning about control
coredata.prism:publicationName: IEEE International Conference on Emerging Technologies and Factory Automation, ETFA
coredata.dc:publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

abstract.ce:para: Qualitative models are better suited for some tasks than the traditional quantitative, or numerical models. These tasks include diagnosis, generating explanation of the system's behavior and designing novel devices from first principles. It is shown by an example how a qualitative modeling approach can be applied to the control of a dynamic system. The example used is the balancing of a pole on a cart. A control rule is derived from a qualitative model of the pole-and-cart system. This rule is shown to be a straightforward qualitative abstraction of the "classical" control rule derived from the differential equations model of this system.

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Ministry of Science and Technology of the Republic of Slovenia
xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Ministry of Science and Technology of the People's Republic of China

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Part of tliis work was done during the author's visit at the Stratliclyde University, Glasgow, Scotland. The work was partly supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology of the Republic of Slovenia. I would like to thank Sa50 Dieroski who wrote the pole-and-cart simulator used in this study, and observed the correspondence between the classical control rule and the qualitative rule derived in this paper. Donald Micliie discovered inconsistency in an earlier version of this paper which required major changes. Other people who helped with suggestions and discussion include: Z. Bing, P.C. Franzone, E. Grant, L. Ironi, D.

abstract.ce:para: Qualitative models are better suited for some tasks than the traditional quantitative, or numerical models. These tasks include diagnosis, generating explanation of the system's behavior and designing novel devices from first principles. It is shown by an example how a qualitative modeling approach can be applied to the control of a dynamic system. The example used is the balancing of a pole on a cart. A control rule is derived from a qualitative model of the pole-and-cart system. This rule is shown to be a straightforward qualitative abstraction of the "classical" control rule derived from the differential equations model of this system.
